revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=January 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2012}} {{Infobox organization | image = File:ThamesDP logo.jpg | abbreviation = TDP | formation = 2008 | type = <!-- [[Governmental organization|GO]], [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]], [[Intergovernmental organization|IGO]], [[International nongovernmental organization|INGO]], etc --> | status = <!-- ad hoc, treaty, foundation, etc --> | purpose = Promotion of the historic River Thames | professional_title = <!-- for professional associations --> | headquarters = | location = London | website = {{url|thamesdiscovery.org}} | remarks = | footnotes = }}
The '''Thames Discovery Programme''' is a [[community archaeology]] project, focusing on the archaeology of the River [[Thames]] on the [[Tideway]]. The Thames Discovery Programme (TDP) was launched in October 2008 and until September 2011, the project was supported by the [[National Lottery (United Kingdom)|National Lottery]] and a grant from the [[Heritage Lottery Fund]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hlf.org.uk/Pages/Home.aspx |title=Heritage Lottery Fund |publisher=Hlf.org.uk |accessdate=13 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111211220147/http://www.hlf.org.uk/Pages/Home.aspx |archivedate=11 December 2011 }}</ref> The project is designed to communicate an understanding and informed enjoyment of the historic Thames to the widest possible audience, and to train and support members of the public (the Foreshore Recording and Observation Group or FROG) to monitor and record the [[archaeology]] of the foreshore during the lifetime of the project, and into the future.
The project builds on initiatives pioneered by the Museum of London’s Thames Archaeological Survey<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thamesdiscovery.org/riverpedia/the-thames-archaeological-survey |title=Thames Archaeological Survey |publisher=Thamesdiscovery.org |date=12 February 2010 |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref> that took place from 1993–1999, the work of commercial archaeological units, such as [[Museum of London Archaeology Service|Museum of London Archaeology]]<ref name="museumoflondonarchaeology1">{{cite web|url=http://www.museumoflondonarchaeology.org.uk/|title=Museum of London Archaeology |publisher=museumoflondonarchaeology.org.uk |accessdate=30 January 2012}}</ref> and the Thames Explorer Trust’s innovative education projects. Over three years, archaeologists from the programme surveyed 20 archaeological sites along the tidal Thames in the Greater London area, supported by the work of the Foreshore Recording and Observation Group or FROG,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thamesdiscovery.org/about/the_frog |title=The FROG |publisher=Thamesdiscovery.org |date=1 January 2010 |accessdate=31 January 2012}}</ref> who monitor the surveyed sites for changes, as the daily tides scour away the remaining archaeological features. The FROG is made up of volunteer members of the public, who are trained in foreshore recording techniques, the history and archaeology of the River Thames, health and safety and participation in digital media by the TDP team.
The TDP currently has a small staff team and is hosted by [[Museum of London Archaeology Service|Museum of London Archaeology]].<ref name="museumoflondonarchaeology1"/> Other partners and supporters include the Thames Explorer Trust,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thames-explorer.org.uk/ |title=Thames Explorer Trust |publisher=Thames-explorer.org.uk |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref> the [[Museum of London]],<ref>[http://www.museumoflondon.org.uk/English/ Museum of London] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091222235451/http://www.museumoflondon.org.uk/English/ |date=22 December 2009 }}</ref> the [[Port of London Authority]],<ref>{{cite web|author=Port of London – www.pla.co.uk |url=http://www.pla.co.uk/ |title=Port of London Authority |publisher=Pla.co.uk |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref> [[English Heritage]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/ |title=English Heritage |publisher=English Heritage |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref> and the [[University College London]] [[UCL Institute of Archaeology|Institute of Archaeology]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ucl.ac.uk/archaeology/ |title=Institute of Archaeology |publisher=Ucl.ac.uk |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref><ref name="Cohen">{{cite journal |last= Cohen |first= Nathalie |authorlink= |author2=Gustav Milne |author3=Eliott Wagg |date= 2012-12-01|title=The Thames Discovery Programme: Public Engagement and Research on London’s Foreshore |journal=Archaeology International |volume= 15 |issue= |pages= 99–106 |id= |url=https://dx.doi.org/10.5334/ai.1506 |doi=10.5334/ai.1506|pmid= }}</ref>
== Discoveries == [[File:Recording the causeway at Isleworth.JPG|thumb|Recording the causeway at Isleworth]] Using data generated by the Thames Archaeological Survey, the Thames Discovery Programme selected twenty key sites across the [[Greater London]] area for further recording and on-going monitoring during 2008 - 2011. The first site chosen was [[Custom House, City of London|Custom House, London]]; in February 2009, FROG members recorded the causeway, parts of the 1819 riverside wall, the Custom House [[gridiron plan|gridiron]], the remains of two [[ship|vessels]] partly buried on the foreshore and a multi-phase [[revetment]] structure located under [[Billingsgate]] Wharf.
In April 2009, an examination of access to the foreshore at [[Isleworth]] included recording the 20th century boat [[slipway]] and the remains of the Victorian ‘Church Ferry’ [[causeway]].
During low tides in June and July 2009, survey and recording at [[Charlton, London]], formerly the location of Castle’s Shipbreakers Yard focused on the ‘stack’ of very large ships timbers surviving at the top of the foreshore which represent the remains of one or more [[warship]] class vessels.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23724819-volunteers-hunt-bank-of-thames-for-clues-of-lost-victorian-warships.do |title=Volunteers hunt bank of Thames for clues of lost Victorian warships |work=Evening Standard |location=London |date=28 July 2009 |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref> [[Nautical]] remains are very well represented at this site where, in addition to the ‘stack’, we have also discovered a slipway constructed of reused ship and boat timbers, as well as the remains of at least three smaller vessels. During the 2009 Summer Season, teams worked at Alderman Stairs (near [[St Katharine Docks]]), [[Putney]] and [[Bermondsey]]. In November 2009, the first FROG-led project at Carrara Wharf in [[Fulham]] recorded part of the 1729 bridge to [[Putney]], while a TDP survey earlier in the year on the foreshore in front of [[Fulham Palace]] found [[Iron Age]] timber piles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://shepherdsbush.ealinggazette.co.uk/2009/11/fulham-foreshore-reveals-ancie.html |title=Fulham foreshore reveals ancient secrets |publisher=Shepherdsbush.ealinggazette.co.uk |accessdate=2014-03-24}}</ref>
During January 2010, investigations on the [[Isle of Dogs]] with the Thames and Field Metal Detecting Society<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thamesandfield.com/ |title=Thames and Field Metal Detecting Society |publisher=Thamesandfield.com |accessdate=30 January 2012}}</ref> discovered the remains of a human skeleton, dating to the early 18th century.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thamesdiscovery.org/frog-blog/discoveries-on-the-isle-of-dogs |title=Discoveries on the Isle of Dogs |publisher=Thamesdiscovery.org |date=7 January 2010 |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref>
[[File:Tower Buckle.jpg|thumb|left|A buckle found on the Tower of London foreshore in July 2010]] During the 2010 Summer Season, work continued on the [[Isle of Dogs]], recording the remains of the slipways used during the launch of the [[SS Great Eastern]], the last project of engineer [[Isambard Kingdom Brunel]]. In July 2010, the TDP team and the FROG worked on the foreshore at the [[Tower of London]], undertaking survey and recording of an area normally closed to the public. Sections of the riverside wall<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thamesdiscovery.org/frog-blog/tower-of-london-fieldwork-report |title=Tower of London Fieldwork Report |publisher=Thamesdiscovery.org |date=4 August 2010 |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref> were recorded and data collected to create a contour survey of the foreshore surface.
The team also worked with members of the Society of Thames Mudlarks and the [[Portable Antiquities Scheme]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.finds.org.uk/ |title=Portable Antiquities Scheme |publisher=Finds.org.uk |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref> to record artefacts found on the surface. The TDP field team then moved to [[Greenwich]] where the riverside wall was again examined, together with parts of a Tudor timber jetty and a newly discovered medieval structure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thamesdiscovery.org/frog-blog/greenwich-fieldwork-report |title=Greenwich Fieldwork Report |publisher=Thamesdiscovery.org |date=11 September 2010 |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref> The project also featured on the BBC's [[Digging for Britain]]. During late August 2010, work was undertaken at two sites in West London,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thamesdiscovery.org/frog-blog/strand-on-the-green-frog-report |title=Strand on the Green Report |publisher=Thamesdiscovery.org |date=23 September 2010 |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref> while in September, fieldwork was undertaken at Tripcockness near the [[Royal Arsenal]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thamesdiscovery.org/frog-blog/ballast-blog |title=Tripcockness Fieldwork Report |publisher=Thamesdiscovery.org |date=12 September 2010 |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref> and [[Rotherhithe]].
In January 2011, the project published the results of recent investigations at Vauxhall,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thamesdiscovery.org/frog-blog/london-s-oldest-find-discovered-at-vauxhall |title=Vauxhall discoveries |publisher=Thamesdiscovery.org |date=6 January 2011 |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref> where the remains of the oldest structure so far discovered in the London area, dating to the late Mesolithic period, have been recorded by the Thames Discovery Programme, English Heritage and the Museum of London.
During the 2011 summer field season, the TDP worked at [[Brentford]], recording the remains of two vessels abandoned on the foreshore, and at [[Wapping]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thamesdiscovery.org/frog-blog/raindrops-keep-falling |title=Raindrops keep falling |publisher=Thamesdiscovery.org |date=9 August 2011 |accessdate=30 January 2012}}</ref> surveying the watermans' causeway and nautical remains. Further fieldwork was also undertaken at Greenwich<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thamesdiscovery.org/frog-blog/greenwich-fieldwork-update|title=Greenwich fieldwork update |publisher=Thamesdiscovery.org |date=12 June 2011 |accessdate=30 January 2012}}</ref> and at the Tower of London foreshore.
== Outreach and events == [[File:Recording the gridiron at Custom House, London.jpg|thumb|Recording the gridiron at Custom House]] The Thames Discovery Programme runs a programme of events and activities designed to engage the public with the archaeology and history of the river. [[Outreach]] activities undertaken by the project including public lectures, small exhibitions, information stands, guided walks on the foreshore, observation of the FROG members in action on site and events for families and school groups, seminars, workshops and conferences.
In 2009 the Thames Discovery Programme worked with a number of different organisations including Fulham Palace,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fulhampalace.org/ |title=Fulham Palace |publisher=Fulham Palace |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref> Historic Royal Palaces,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hrp.org.uk/ |title=Historic Royal Palaces |publisher=Hrp.org.uk |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref> Gunnersbury Park Museum,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hounslow.info/arts/gunnersburyparkmuseum/ |title=Gunnersbury Park |publisher=Hounslow.gov |accessdate=30 January 2012}}</ref> Camden Young Archaeologists Club,<ref>[http://www.camdenyoungarchaeologists.org.uk/default.asp Camden Young Archaeologists Club] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080325072443/http://www.camdenyoungarchaeologists.org.uk/default.asp |date=25 March 2008 }}</ref> the University of East London,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uel.ac.uk/ |title=University of East London |publisher=Uel.ac.uk |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref> Thames Explorer Trust, Thames Estuary Partnership, the London Archaeological Archive and Research Centre,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.museumoflondon.org.uk/Collections-Research/LAARC/ |title=LAARC |publisher=museumoflondon.org.uk |accessdate=30 January 2012}}</ref> the Worshipful Company of Antiquarian Collectors, the Museum of London and [[Museum in Docklands]]. During 2010 and 2011, the team again worked with a number of different organisations including the [[Royal Society for the Protection of Birds]] at [[Rainham Marshes]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rspb.org.uk/reserves/guide/r/rainhammarshes/ |title=RSPB Rainham |publisher=Rspb.org.uk |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref> Discover Greenwich,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oldroyalnavalcollege.org/discover-greenwich/ |title=Discover Greenwich |publisher=Oldroyalnavalcollege.org |date=23 March 2010 |accessdate=13 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141107003836/http://www.oldroyalnavalcollege.org/discover-greenwich/ |archivedate=7 November 2014 }}</ref> Historic Royal Palaces at the [[Tower of London]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hrp.org.uk/TowerOfLondon/ |title=Tower of London |publisher=hrp.org.uk |year=2012 |accessdate=30 January 2012}}</ref> and [[Southwark Cathedral]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cathedral.southwark.anglican.org/ |title=Southwark Cathedral |publisher=cathedral.southwark.anglican.org |year=2012 |accessdate=30 January 2012}}</ref>
The project also featured in the Archaeology in Action gallery<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.museumoflondon.org.uk/London-Wall/Whats-on/Exhibitions-Displays/Archaeology-in-Action.htm |title=Archaeology in Action |publisher=museumoflondon.org.uk |accessdate=30 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111231193716/http://www.museumoflondon.org.uk/London-Wall/Whats-on/Exhibitions-Displays/Archaeology-in-Action.htm |archivedate=31 December 2011 }}</ref> at the [[Museum of London]]. Thousands of members of the public have visited the [[foreshore]] and attended other events, particularly during the two-week [[Festival of British Archaeology]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://festival.britarch.ac.uk/ |title=Festival of British Archaeology |publisher=Festival.britarch.ac.uk |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref> coordinated by the [[Council for British Archaeology]] in July each year. In July 2009, the Thames Discovery Programme celebrated the Festival at Fulham Palace and on the foreshore<ref>{{cite web|url=http://festival.britarch.ac.uk/blog |title=Thames Discovery at Fulham Palace |publisher=Festival.britarch.ac.uk |accessdate=13 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303222307/http://festival.britarch.ac.uk/blog |archivedate=3 March 2012 }}</ref> and in 2010 the team were at the [[Tower of London]], [[Hall Place]] and the Museum of London.
A detailed report<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thamesdiscovery.org/about/community-archaeology-report |title=Community Archaeology Report |publisher=thamesdiscovery.org |accessdate=30 January 2012}}</ref> on the events, activities and fieldwork undertaken by the Thames Discovery Programme during the Heritage Lottery Funded phase of the project (October 2008-September 2011) is available on the project website.
== Awards ==
The TDP website won the award for the "Best Representation of Archaeology in the Media" at the 2010 British Archaeological Awards<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britarch.ac.uk/awards/ |title=British Archaeological Awards |publisher=Britarch.ac.uk |date=1 November 2011 |accessdate=13 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120111235609/http://www.britarch.ac.uk/awards/ |archivedate=11 January 2012 }}</ref> and in February 2011, the project was one of five from across Britain nominated by [[Current Archaeology]] as "Best Research Project of 2011".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archaeologyawards.org/2011/research-project-of-the-year.htm |title=Research Project of the Year |publisher=Archaeologyawards.org |date=26 November 2010 |accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref> In July 2012, the project won the award for "Best Community Archaeology Project" at the British Archaeological Awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.archaeologyuk.org/awards/ |title=British Archaeological Awards |publisher=Britarch.ac.uk |date=18 July 2012 |accessdate=10 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120728095608/http://www.archaeologyuk.org/awards/ |archivedate=28 July 2012 }}</ref>
In 2013, TDP Project Director [[Gustav Milne]] was nominated as one of Current Archaeology's "Archaeologists of the Year" and the Thames Discovery Programme won the Archaeology Training Forum's Training Award, which was presented at the IfA Conference in Birmingham. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thamesdiscovery.org/frog-blog/atf-award-winners |title=ATF Award |publisher=thamesdiscovery.org.uk |accessdate=20 April 2013}}</ref>
== References == <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using<ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist|2}}
== External links == * [http://www.thamesdiscovery.org/ Thames Discovery Programme project website]
[[Category:History of the River Thames]] [[Category:Maritime archaeology]] [[Category:History organisations based in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Port of London]] [[Category:Archaeological projects]] [[Category:Public archaeology]]

{{Refimprove|date=November 2006}}
'''Thematic structure''' is a concept in [[linguistics]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Roca |first=I. M. |year=1992 |title=Thematic Structure: Its Role in Grammar |publisher=Walter de Gruyter |isbn=9783110134063}}</ref> When people talk, there are purposes in three separable parts of utterances, the act of speech, the [[Proposition|propositional content]] and the thematic structure. Because speaking is cooperative, in order that the speaking can be effective in the [[conversation]], speakers have to pay attention to their listeners’ knowledge, state of mind and level of understanding. Speakers can assume that listeners know or do not know what speakers are talking about.
According to [[Michael Halliday]], the speakers’ judgements about the listeners’ current mental states are reflected in what is called the thematic structure used.
The thematic structure has three main functions: *To convey given information and new information *To subject and predicate *To frame and insert
A thematic structure is a preoccupying conception of a proposition which runs throughout a media text, usually around an initiating topic. It strategically ties together a number of more specific conception or statements on the basis of particular social forms of knowledge and social forms of perception and belief. A thematic structure helps to make a media text coherent -- it orients a text around a central theme of a strand of related themes running through a story. (reference: David Deacon(2007), Researching communications,p174)
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Thematic Structure}} [[Category:Linguistics]]

revision.text:
'''Vladimir Nikolayevich Toporov''' ({{lang-ru|Влади́мир Никола́евич Топоро́в}}; 5 July 1928 in [[Moscow]]{{spaced ndash}}5 December 2005 in Moscow) was a leading [[Russia]]n [[Philology|philologist]] associated with the [[Tartu-Moscow semiotic school]]. His wife was [[Tatyana Elizarenkova]].
Toporov authored more than 1500 works, including ''Akhmatova and Dante'' (1972), ''Towards the Reconstruction of the Indo-European Rite'' (1982), ''Aeneas: a Man of Destiny'' (1993), ''Myth. Rite. Symbol. Image'' (1995), ''Holiness and Saints in the Russian Spiritual Culture'' (1998), and ''Petersburg Text of Russian Literature'' (2003). He translated the [[Dhammapada]] into Russian and supervised the ongoing edition of the most complete vocabulary of the [[Prussian language]] to date (5 volumes).
Among Toporov's many honours were the [[USSR State Prize]] (1990), which he turned down to voice his protest against the repressive policies of the Soviet administration in [[Lithuania]]; the first ever [[Solzhenitsyn Prize]] (1998), and the [[Andrei Bely Prize]] for 2004. He was a member of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences]] and many other scholarly societies.
== External links == * {{citation |url=http://www.lituanus.org/2007/07_2_01%20Sabaliauskas.html |title=Remembering Vladimir Toporov |last=Sabaliauskas |first=Algirdas |year=2007 |volume=53 |issue=2 |journal=Lituanus}} *{{ru icon}} [http://www.museum.ru/N24733 Obituary by the Russian Ministry of Culture]
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Toporov, Vladimir}} [[Category:Balticists]] [[Category:Russian philologists|Toporov]] [[Category:Russian literary critics|Toporov]] [[Category:Russian semioticians|Toporov]] [[Category:Full Members of the USSR Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:Full Members of the Russian Academy of Sciences|Toporov]] [[Category:1928 births|Toporov]] [[Category:2005 deaths|Toporov]] [[Category:Moscow State University alumni]] [[Category:Buddhist studies scholars]] [[Category:Researchers of Slavic religion]] [[Category:Solzhenitsyn Prize winners]] [[Category:Paleolinguists]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Mapcc08.png|thumb|450px| {{Legend-table|lang=en |title=2008 World Map of the Control of Corruption Index, which measures the degree to which corruption is perceived to exist among businesses, public officials and politicians. ---- |#00bb00|90-100th percentile* |#66ff66|75-90th percentile |#ffff00|50-75th percentile |#ffbb00|25-50th percentile |#ff7777|10-25th percentile |#cc0000|0-10th percentile ---- ''*'' [[Percentile]] rank indicates the percentage of countries worldwide that rate below the selected country. Higher values indicate better governance ratings.}}]] -->
Based on a long-standing research program of the [[World Bank]], the '''Worldwide Governance Indicators''' capture six key dimensions of [[governance]] (Voice & Accountability, Political Stability and Lack of Violence, [[Government]] Effectiveness, Regulatory Quality, [[Rule of law|Rule of Law]], and Control of [[political corruption|Corruption]]) between 1996 and present. They measure the quality of governance in over 200 [[country|countries]], based on close to 40 data sources produced by over 30 organizations worldwide and are updated annually since 2002.
The governance indicators contribute to the growing empirical research of governance which have provided [[activism|activists]] and [[Reform movement|reformers]] worldwide with [[advocacy]] tools for policy reform and monitoring. The indicators, and the underlying data behind them, are part of the current research and opinions that have reinforced the experiences and observations of reform-minded individuals in government, [[civil society]], and the private sector, that [[good governance]] is key for [[international development|development]].<ref name="Kaufman">Kaufmann, Daniel and Kraay, Aart, [http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=316861 "Growth Without Governance"] (November 2002). World Bank Policy Research Working Paper No. 2928.</ref> Their growing recognition of the link between good governance and successful development, as empirical evidence suggests,<ref name="Kaufman"/> has stimulated demand for monitoring the quality of governance across countries and within individual countries over time. Virtually all of the individual data sources underlying the aggregate indicators are, along with the aggregate indicators themselves, publicly available.
The Worldwide Governance Indicators are a compilation of the perceptions of a very diverse group of respondents, collected in large number of [[Statistical survey|surveys]] and other cross-country [[Evaluation|assessments]] of governance. Some of these instruments capture the views of firms, individuals, and public officials in the countries being assessed. Others reflect the views of [[NGO]]s and aid donors with considerable experience in the countries being assessed, while others are based on the assessments of commercial risk-rating agencies.
A complementary vision of the macro-level Worldwide Governance Indicators are the [[World Bank Governance Surveys]], which are country level governance assessment tools developed by the [[World Bank Institute]].
==Criticisms==
The Worldwide Governance Indicators offer a useful snapshot of some perceptions of a country’s quality of governance but researchers have pointed out significant problems in their construction. These critiques have been extensively rebutted by the WGI authors in several publications.<ref>[http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=965077 Kaufmann, Daniel, Aart Kraay and Massimo Mastruzzi (2007). "The Worldwide Governance Indicators: Answering the Critics". World Bank Policy Research Working Paper No 4149.]</ref><ref>Kaufmann, Daniel, Aart Kraay and Massimo Mastruzzi (2010). "Response to: What Do the Worldwide Governance Indicators Measure". ''European Journal of Development Research''.</ref><ref>[http://siteresources.worldbank.org/DEC/Resources/ResponseToKnackLangbein.pdf Kaufmann, Daniel, Aart Kraay and Massimo Mastruzzi (2010). "Response to Knack-Langbein".]</ref>
These critics have claimed that users often fail to take into account or are not aware of their limitations. Criticisms include:<ref>{{cite paper |title=The Politics of Governance Ratings |first=C. |last=Arndt |first2=C. |last2=Oman |year=2008 |work=Working Paper MGSoG/2008/WP003 |url=http://www.governance.unimaas.nl/training_activities/aau/download/Papers/The%20politics%20of%20governance%20ratings_arndt.pdf }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |first=M. |last=Thomas |year=2009 |title=What Do the Worldwide Governance Indicators Measure? |journal=European Journal of Development Research |volume=22 |issue=1 |pages=31–54 |doi=10.1057/ejdr.2009.32 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |first=L. |last=Langbein |first2=S. |last2=Knack |year=2010 |title=The Worldwide Governance Indicators: Six, One, or None? |journal=[[Journal of Development Studies]] |volume=46 |issue=2 |pages=350–370 |doi=10.1080/00220380902952399 }}</ref>
* Not reproducible: Many of the indicators underlying each source’s ratings, are not published. * Too complex: The WGI “Control of Corruption” uses 23 combinations of sources just for East Europe and Central Asia. The sheer number and diversity of indicators, produced by others, in a single WGI make it very difficult to understand. * Arbitrary: For example, WGI use the indicator “Environmental regulations hurt competitiveness” from the World Economic Forum’s Executive Opinion Survey, but ignore that Survey’s several questions that give high ratings to countries with a high standard of environmental protection. * Absence of an underlying theory of "good" governance: no normative concept or unifying single theory to distinguish between good or bad governance. When are taxes, labour or environmental regulatory protection desirable and when are they excessive? * Hidden biases: Low weight given to household surveys relative to the weights of expert assessments and firm surveys. For example, Gallup’s World Poll that asks citizens about their exposure to crime gets zero weight for "Rule of Law", but Global Insight Business Risk and Conditions, a U.S. commercial business information provider that measures the crime risk to businesses, gets the third highest weight. * Lack of comparability over time and space: For example, the WGI “Control of Corruption” for Eastern Europe and Central Asia has 23 different combinations of sources, but only four pair of countries ratings are based on a common set of sources. * Lack of actionability: WGI offers little guidance to concrete actions to improve the quality of governance. For example, an indicator for Rule of Law "how secure business people feel about their property" not ''why'' they feel that way. * Over-selling: The World Bank Institute advertises its WGIs as "reliable measurements of governance", but for example gives the misleading impression that the views of ordinary citizens are well represented, making the indicators particularly attractive to donor agencies concerned about the poor. WBI heavily stressed inclusion of the Gallup World Poll, a cross-country household survey available for a large number of countries, but Gallup’s World Poll gets zero weight on two WGIs, marginal weight on two other WGIs and provides no data for the remaining two. * Lack of conceptual clarity: “[T]he six governance indicators measure a broad underlying concept of ‘effective governance’ … they appear to say the same thing, with different words … the six indexes do not discriminate usefully among different aspects of governance. Rather, each of the indexes – whatever its label – merely reflects perceptions of the quality of governance more broadly. An implication is that they may have limited use as guides for policymakers, and for academic studies of the causes and consequences of ‘good governance’ as well… their availability may well have crowded out efforts at measuring the impact of institutions as they really exist in a particular place on real outcomes."
==Strengths==
Despite the above noted limitations and concerns recent econometric research looking at how reliable some of these indicators are, vis-a-vis data collected from natural experiments and other observational surveys, have actually concluded that the Good Governance Indicators do in fact seem to be measuring, albeit imperfectly, levels of corruption and government effectiveness. <ref> {{Cite web|url=http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/113281515516828746/pdf/WPS8299.pdf |title= Can We Measure the Power of the Grabbing Hand? A Comparative Analysis of Different Indicators of Corruption|last=Hamilton|first= Alexander|date=2017|website=World Bank Policy Research Working Paper Series|}} </ref>.
==See also== *[[Good governance]] *[[Ibrahim Index of African Governance]] *[[Governance]] *[[Government Performance and Results Act]] (GPRA) and particularly [http://xml.fido.gov/stratml/references/PL111-532StratML.htm#SEC10 section 10] of the GPRA Modernization Act (GPRAMA), which requires U.S. federal agencies to publish their performance indicators in machine-readable format, like [[Strategy Markup Language]] (StratML) -- a good practice for agencies at all levels of government worldwide.

<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Zenit-El-Lissitzky.png|thumb|right|Cover of ''Zenit 17/18'' (October/November 1922) with a cover designed by [[El Lissitzky]]]] --> '''Zenitism''' ({{Lang-sh|Zenitizam / Зенитизам}}) was an [[art]] movement in [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]] from 1921 until 1926, first in [[Zagreb]] from 1921 to 1924 and from 1924 in [[Belgrade]]. The movement was mainly involved in [[visual arts]], [[graphic design]], [[poetry]], [[literature]], [[theatre]], [[film]], [[architecture]] and [[music]].<ref>http://digital.nb.rs/zenit/english.html</ref> Like other avant-garde movements at the time, it held anti-war, anti-bourgeois and anti-nationalist views and rejected traditional culture and art. Micić defined the movement as "abstract metacosmic expressionism."
Most of its ideas were communicated through the [[Zenit (magazine)|Zenit]] magazine which [[Ljubomir Micić]] launched and which published 43 issues.
==The movement==
The movement was established following [[World War I]], during which [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]] lost a million inhabitants.<ref>Erlikman, Vadim (2004). Poteri narodonaseleniia v XX veke : spravochnik. Moscow. {{ISBN|5-93165-107-1}}.</ref> Although some artists from the region were known in Europe, Zenitism was the first notable art movement from the Balkans in Europe.
<!--==''Barbarogenius''== -->
